Jane Lynch , the 50-year-old actress- who plays scathing cheerleading coach Sue Sylvester on the US TV show- believes there are many similarities between the teacher and the straight-talking talent show judge. She said: If ever there was a guy who tells it like it is, then it's Simon Cowell . You could definitely look at Sue and say there's a lot of Simon Cowell in her.`` He's a great inspiration for the character of Sue- there is a lot that I can take from him and put into her. If you want to know where is the consumer heat, the things that people want to get their hands on, it's Xbox and Xbox Kinect. I think about my own family. My wife used to say,` No, no, that's the machine the boys use,' and now she says,` Yeah, I want to go watch movies. Let's go play the dance game.' Steve Ballmer continued:`` It opens up accessibility to family entertainment because with the Kinect, you control these systems with your body, with your voice. Benko believes Mike Pence could easily rally the Tea Party, which provided the GOP with the needed muscle to take back the House of Representatives and make considerable gains in the Senate during the 2010 congressional elections. You need people and you need money, and both of them are just out there waiting for an extraordinary person to unite behind, Benko told CNSNews.com.`` He[ Mike Pence ] is a true constitutionalist, which is at the core of the DNA of us tea partiers. '' he said.`` Larry, Sergey Brin and I have worked exceptionally closely together for over a decade- and we anticipate working together for a long time to come.'' Page praised Eric Schmidt for an outstanding job leading Google for the last decade.`` There is no other CEO in the world that could have kept such headstrong founders so deeply involved and still run the business so brilliantly, he said.`` Eric Schmidt is a tremendous leader and I have learned innumerable lessons from him. His advice and efforts will be invaluable to me as I start in this new role,'' he said

release for Martin Luther King Day doesn't have much to do with civil rights, strictly speaking. It addresses the shooting of Rep. Gabrielle Giffords of Arizona and the rhetorical and budgetary attacks on public employees of recent months. ALBANY, NY( 01/14/2011)- The recent horrific events in Tuscon have saddened us all. However, from every tragedy lessons can be learned and the attention given by many to the contribution of violent rhetoric as cause for the shootings may be just the opening to bring civility back to our public discourse. I am further bolstered by the genuine joy expressed by U.S. Senator Kirsten Gillibrand in her account of the awakening of her friend and colleague Congresswoman Gabrielle Giffords during a visit to the shooting victim's hospital room.
